qas.question: What was the claimed target of a terrorist attack according to a late 2010 Sun front page story?
What was the television program that would have been affected by the attack?
What did the Manchester police say about these claimed attacks?

answers.text: categorically denied having "been made aware of any threat from Al-Qaeda or any other proscribed organisation."

qas.question: Who negotiated an apology from The Sun for its misreporting of this story?
Who was responsible for the 2011 Norway attacks?

context: On 9 December 2010, The Sun published a front-page story claiming that terrorist group Al-Qaeda had threatened a terrorist attack on <a0_0>Granada Television in Manchester<a0_0/> to disrupt the episode of the soap opera <a1_0>Coronation Street<a1_0/> to be transmitted live that evening. The paper cited unnamed sources, claiming "cops are throwing a ring of steel around tonight's live episode of Coronation Street over fears it has been targeted by Al-Qaeda." Later that morning, however, Greater Manchester Police <a2_0>categorically denied having "been made aware of any threat from Al-Qaeda or any other proscribed organisation."<a2_0/> The Sun published a small correction on 28 December, admitting "that while cast and crew were subject to full body searches, there was no specific threat from Al-Qaeda as we reported." The apology had been negotiated by <a3_0>the Press Complaints Commission<a3_0/>. For the day following the 2011 Norway attacks The Sun produced an early edition blaming the massacre on al-Qaeda. Later the perpetrator was revealed to be <a4_0>Anders Behring Breivik,<a4_0/> a Norwegian nationalist.
